parts: Name these theories that suggests that fundamental particles are actually different vibrations of small loops. It competes with loop quantum gravity as the most likely correct theory of everything.
Theories of everything necessarily must include a theory of this type, which unifies the strong and electroweak forces, without unifying gravity.
M theory was first posited by this Princeton physicist, who won a Fields medal for his work. He also names a theorem with Weinberg that implies that the graviton cannot be a composite particle.

In issue #50 of this character's first series, he briefly gives up his superhero identity, in a story entitled "this character No More!" He gains his powers from a radioactive arachnid and fights villains like Doctor Octopus.

Spider-Man was created by writer Stan Lee and this reclusive artist, for the 15th issue of Marvel's Amazing Fantasy. His other characters include Mr. A and Doctor Strange, soon to be played by Benedict Cumberbatch.

Ditko also created this character from DC Comics, who first appeared in Showcase #73. With civilian identity talk show host Jack Ryder, this character has yellow skin and green hair, along with a crazed personality.
Name this festival dedicated to the worship of Durga, with a name meaning "nine nights" in Sanskrit.
This other more-well-known Hindu festival celebrates the return of Rama to his throne by lighting candles, lanterns, and the like.
An important element of Diwali is giving prayers to this goddess of wealth. Gifts are typically exchanged and shopping happens afterwards.
Name this author of Nocturnes and Ce que je crois. Jean-Paul Sartre wrote an introduction for his compilation of Francophone poetry entitled Anthology of New Negro and Malagasy Poetry.

Senghor helped develop this literary ideology, which affirms international African solidarity and identity, and which takes its name from a French antiblack slur. Its name first appeared in the third issue of L'Etudiant Noir.
Another founder of NÃ©gritude includes this Martinican poet of "Notes from a Return to the Native Land", "Discourse on Colonialism," who portrayed Caliban as a hero in Une TÃªmpete.
This photographer's works include Jewish Giant, taken at Home with His Parents in the Bronx. She also took the photo Child with Toy Hand Grenade in Central Park.
Two children appear in this photograph by Dorothea Lange, which is named for and depicts Florence Thompson.

This 1992 book by Sally Mann was controversial for including several nude shots of her own children. Her son Emmett refused to let one picture appear in the book because it showed him with his socks on his hands.
Name this character who is targeted by a lynch mob led by Curley in revenge for his having killed Curley's wife, but is mercifully shot in the back of the head before they can get to him.
Lennie is killed by his friend George at the end of this 1937 novella by John Steinbeck.

Lennie's death is foreshadowed by the execution of the ancient dog belonging to this other ranch worker. This aging one-handed man offers to contribute his life savings to George and Lennie's rabbit-farm plan.
Manuel Belgrano and Jose de San MartÃ­n were both generals from this modern-day nation, which was later ruled by Juan PerÃ³n and his wife Isabel.
San MartÃ­n met with fellow revolutionary SimÃ³n BolÃ­var to decide the fate of Peru at this conference, where the two negotiated in private at the city hall with no records being kept.

Guayaquil is in this present-day Andean country, which emerged after Sucre's victory at Pichincha. Juan JosÃ© Flores collaborated with Maria Christina of the Two Sicilies to reinstall the Spanish throne here.

answers: pig [or equivalents of any sex, such as warthogs or spoinks]
parts: Name this philosophical text which advises: "always run to the short way, and the short way is the natural." Its second book ends by suggesting its author wrote part of it in Carnuntum.
The second book ends "This in Carnuntum" because the Meditations were written by this Roman emperor while he was campaigning in modern-day Slovakia.

In the tenth book of the Meditations, Marcus Aurelius compares "every man who is grieved at anything or discontented" to be like this animal, which "kicks and screams" when killed because it is not "reasonable."
Name these Norse seafaring people whose members include Leif Erikson. They often used longships in their conquests.
Byzantine emperors employed Vikings as members of this personal guard. They were first created under Basil the Bulgar-Slayer and eventually included Anglo-Saxons.
This Viking commander sieged Paris in 885 AD and founded the Duchy of Normandy after the land was ceded to him by Charles the Simple. He passed the duchy on to his son William I Longsword.

answers: Edward Charles Pickering [prompt on "Pickering"; do not accept "William Pickering"]
parts: This astronomer employed a "harem" to compute astronomical data and together with one of his employees, Williamina Fleming, created a classification system for stars that formed the Henry Draper Catalogue.
This astronomer's Ph.D. thesis first concluded that hydrogen was the primary component in stars, which notably dismayed Henry Norris Russell. She also related spectral class to temperature.

Both Pickering and Payne spent their astronomical careers at this university; Payne graduated from the nearby Radcliffe college. Pound and Rebka confirmed gravitational redshift at its Jefferson Laboratory.

answers: Hunahpu and Xbalanque [or the Hero Twins]
parts: Name these two brothers who defeated Seven Macaw and his sons and later became the sun and the moon.

The story of the hero twins is told in the Popul Vuh, the primary mythological text of this civilization. The ballgame played by the Hero Twins, in which the losers are sacrificed, was played by this Mesoamerican civilization.
The Popul Vuh was preserved and transcribed by this Dominican priest.

answers: USS Baltimore Affair [accept Baltimore Crisis or anything synonymous]
parts: Identify this American Naval captain whose lectures at the Naval War College on the Influence of Sea Power Upon History inspired Theodore Roosevelt's build-up of the American Navy.

Mahan's ideas may have influenced the robust American response to this 1891 attack on US sailors in Valparaiso returning to the attack's namesake ship; Benjamin Harrison threatened war and Chile paid compensation to end this dispute.

American naval primacy was showcased during the Spanish-American War at this 1898 battle when Commodore Dewey sunk most of the Spanish Fleet in the namesake bay outside the capital of the Philippines.

answers: A, C, and E-flat [accept in any order; do not accept "E"]
parts: In the key of G major, the dominant is this note, whose major key Johann Pachelbel used to write a canon.

A chord progression from the dominant to the tonic characterizes the authentic type of this musical figure. Musical phrases end with these constructions, which also have plagal, half, and deceptive varieties.
If a dominant seventh chord is rooted on F, it contains these other three notes.
Name this color field painter, who painted the Seagram Murals, as well as the fourteen paintings that can be found at his namesake "Chapel" in Texas.
Rothko was part of the loosely defined color field movement, which is a style of this kind of painting. This type of "expressionism" names a style practiced by Jackson Pollock.

The sculpture Broken Obelisk, which can be found at Rothko Chapel, was made by this other artist. As a color field painter he created the series Who's Afraid of Red, Yellow, and Blue? and the Stations of the Cross series.

answers: The War of the Rough Wooing [or the Eight Years' War or the Nine Years' War]
Mary, Queen of Scots [do not accept "Bloody Mary" or "Mary Tudor"]
parts: Name this 1543-1551 war which was concluded by the Treaty of Norham and involved the betrothal of Edward VI.
The War of the Rough Wooing attempted to arrange a marriage between the six-year old Edward and this infant queen of Scotland. She would later marry both Francis II and Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley.
This father of Mary was killed at the Battle of Solway Moss, leading Mary to succeed him when she was six days old.

Name this author who won a Booker for his novel The Old Devils. The protagonist of his most famous novel gets fired from his university job after a lecture on "Merrie England" turns into a drunken tirade mocking his boss Professor Welch.
Amis attacked the aesthetics and ideology of this literary movement, which was exemplified by poets like Wordsworth, Byron, and Keats, in a poem titled "Against" it.

"Against Romanticism" can be seen as a manifesto for this literary group, which included Amis as well as other English writers like Philip Larkin, Tom Gunn, and Elizabeth Jennings. Its name was coined by Jay. D. Scott.
Name this type of receptor that use ATP to phosphorylate a namesake amino acid after dimerizing. Growth factor receptors are often this type.
The 1989 Nobel Prize was awarded for the discovery of this proto-oncogene in the Rous sarcoma virus, which infects chickens. SH2 and SH3 domains are homologous to this protein.

The JAK-STAT pathway is aberrantly activated in a disease that causes this tissue to become fibrotic. This tissue, which comes in red and yellow types and is aspirated from the pelvis, is where blood cells are synthesized.
Name the more acidic species between 2-chloropropionic acid and 3-chloropropionic acid.
2-chloropropionic acid is more acidic because the negative charge on the oxygen is stabilized by this effect, in which electronegative groups pull electron density through bonds.
The inductive effect is well-established for elements in this group, which includes bromine, chlorine, and fluorine. They are group 17 on the periodic table.
Name these accounts which refer to resources or the right to future benefits for a firm. Examples include cash and inventory.
Equity includes additional paid-in capital and this account, which refers to the nominal price of a stock. This value often differs highly from the actual price at which the stock was issued.
Increases in assets are listed under this term. Conversely, it indicates decreases in liabilities and in equity.
Name this novel in which Arvid Falk becomes a journalist and poet while hanging out with his bohemian friends in the title cafe.
This Swedish author of The Red Room is now more famous for his plays, including The Ghost Sonata, A Dream Play, and Miss Julie.

In this Strindberg play, Captain Adolph and his wife Laura argue about whether Bertha should become an artist or a teacher. Laura tricks her husband into acting insane, thus gaining power over the family's property.
